context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: The Court of Appeals held that Exemption 2 did not exempt the summaries from disclosure and then turned to Exemption 6, and held that Exemption 6, at least in respect of the determination required by that exemption, namely whether a disclosure would constitute a clearly unwarranted invasion of personal privacy of the cadets or the subjects of the summaries, required that the summaries be turned over to the District Court for in camera inspection, and that the Air force cooperate with the judge in redacting the summaries so as to delete personal references and all other identifying information and we affirm the judgment of the Court of Appeals.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: We hold that the in camera procedure, ordered by the Court of Appeals, will further the statutory goal of Exemption 6, which enacts a workable compromise between individual rights and preservation of public rights to government information.

context.speaker: William J. Brennan, Jr.
context.text: These limited statutory exemptions can’t obscure the basic policy that disclosure, not secrecy, is the dominant objective of the Freedom of Information Act and the public does have a substantial concern with the Air Force Academy’s administration of disciplinary procedures that affect the training of Air Force officers and their military careers.

context.text: Finally, the judge instructed the jury that it would not be authorized to consider imposing the sentence of death unless it first found beyond the reasonable doubt one of three relevant statutory aggravating circumstances.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We consider at the outset the basic contention that the punishment of death for the crime of murder is under all circumstance, cruel and un-usual and violation of the Constitution.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: For the reasons that Mr. Justice Powell will summarize thoroughly in announcing our opinion in the case of Proffitt against Florida, we reject that contention.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: We therefore must consider the specific constitutionality of Georgia’s capital sentencing procedures.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In the wake of this Court’s judgment in the Furman case four years ago, Georgia narrowed the class of murderers subject to capital punishment by specifying ten statutory aggravating circumstances, at least one of which must be found by the jury to exist beyond the reasonable doubt before a death sentence can ever be imposed.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: While the jury is permitted to consider any aggravating or mitigating circumstances, it must find and must identify at least one statutory aggravating factor before it may impose a penalty of death.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In this way the juries’ discretion is channeled no longer therefore can a jury wantonly and freakishly imposed the death sentence it is always circumscribed by the legislative guidelines.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: In addition, the review function of the Supreme Court of Georgia affords additional assurance that the constitutional concerns that prompted our decision in Furman are not present in the Georgia procedure applied in this case.

context.speaker: Warren E. Burger
context.text: For the reasons I have summarized, which are set out at considerable lengths in the written opinion the Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Stevens, and I have filed today, we hold that the statutory system under which Gregg was sentenced to death does not violate the Constitution.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and I believe that a trial before such a judge that results in the imprisonment of the defendant is constitutionally intolerable.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It deprives the accused of his right to the effective assistance of counsel guaranteed by the Sixth and Fourteenth Amendments, and deprives him as well of due process of law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: Beginning with the capital case of Powell against Alabama, extending through the felony case of Gideon against Wainwright and culminating in the misdemeanor case of Argersinger against Hamlin.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: And after finding North guilty, Judge Russell proceeded to impose a sentence of imprisonment, although such a sentence was clearly unauthorized by Kentucky law.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But even if it were not possible to demonstrate in a particular case that the lay judge had been incompetent or the trial egregiously unfair, I think that any trial before a wholly untrained lay judge that results in the defendant's imprisonment violates the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment.

context.text: The Court seems to say that these constitutional deficiencies can all be swept under the rug and forgotten because the convicted defendant may have a trial De novo before a qualified judge.

context.text: Mr. Justice Marshall and I cannot agree.

context.text: In the case of Ward against Village of Monroeville, the Court made clear that “the State's trial court procedure cannot be deemed constitutionally acceptable, simply because the State eventually offers a defendant an impartial adjudication. context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The Court today would distinguish the Ward case as directed at the need for independent, neutral, and detached judgment, not at legal training.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: But surely there can be no meaningful constitutional difference between a trial that is fundamentally unfair because of the judge's possible bias, and a trial that is fundamentally unfair because of the judge's ignorance of the law.

context.text: Well, I do not believe Mr. Justice Blackmun, that it is necessary for the general assembly to cover every possible type of medical situation and the series substantiates to render one particular statute constitutional.

context.text: Furthermore you have a case where the woman is pregnant and is married where something has happened in the marriage itself and that condition is either going to yield to an addition to the family which is proximate and immediate, or it is going to be aborted.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: No one can doubt that the death penalty was contemplated when the constitution was adopted.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It was a traditional penalty both in the colonies and in England.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The text of the Fifth Amendment reiterated in part in the Fourteenth Amendment, 75 years later, makes clear the acceptance of capital punishment and in the nearly two centuries of our national existence until 1972, this Court repeatedly and often expressly recognized that capital punishment is not invalid per se.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: In Trop against Dulles, decided in 1958, then Chief Justice Warren, in the same opinion in which he spoke of evolving standard of decency, said this.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: “The death penalty has been employed throughout our history and in a day when it is still widely accepted, it cannot be said to violate the constitutional concept of cruelty.”

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The first major challenge to the per se validity of capital punishment reached this court in 1972 in Furman.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The principal argument presented by petitioners in Furman was that standards of decency had evolved to the point where capital punishment was no longer tolerated in this country.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: It was said then that the Eight Amendment must be construed finally as prohibiting capital punishment for any crime regardless of it's depravity and of it's impact on society.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Petitioners in the prior cases the other day have renewed the standard of decency argument.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But as Mr. Justice White has noted, developments during the four years since Furman have undercut substantially, the assumptions upon which that argument was advanced.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Objective criteria demonstrate that prevailing standards in our country do not reject capital punishment, at least as a sanction in some cases.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The most marked indication of society's endorsement of the death penalty for murder, is a legislative response to Furman.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: There is no conclusive empiric data either proving or disproving, the value of the penalty as a deterrent.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: Yet we may assume, we do assume that there are murders , such as those committed in the heat of passion for which the threat of depth has little or no deterrent effect.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: But there are others, for example those are deliberately planned in advance, where the penalty may well be a deterring factor, and in some cases, such as murder by a life prisoners there is no other adequate sanction.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: The evaluation of the unresolved debate concerning deterrents properly rests, as Mr. Justice White has said with the legislatures.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
context.text: They have the flexibility and the means to ascertain the facts that are quite unavailable to the judiciary.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.speaker: Lewis F. Powell, Jr.

context.text: They have no plan or purpose of exclusiveness any of these schools, then they are open to everyone in the communities or the areas that they serve and race is the only factor that constitutes an absolute bar.

context.text: Now of course they do have other selective characteristics but then so did the swimming pools in the Sullivan and Tillman cases.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: The memberships in those schools, those associations were subject to approval of the board of directors and they had various other kinds of geographic and financial qualifications, but race became the absolute bar.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Now, again with respect to schools, government regulations of schools is a very common thing, as Mr. Justice Rehnquist mentioned earlier in the course of the argument.

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall

context.speaker: Thurgood Marshall
context.text: Now the other very important and very significant thing is that in 1972 Congress, as we noted in our brief, Congress amended Title VII of the Fair Employment Provisions of the Civil Rights Act of the 1964 to apply them to private schools.

context.text: These cases are here by the reason of the grant of writs of certiorari to the United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: The principal issue presented by these consolidated cases is whether a federal law, namely Section 1981 of Volume 42 of the United States Code, prohibits commercially operated private schools from excluding qualified children solely because they are Negroes.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: For these and other reasons, spelled out in some detail in the court's written opinion, we agree with the Court of Appeals that enforcement of Section 1981 in these cases will not work a deprivation of any constitutional right of the defendant schools, of the intervenors or of their pupils or patrons.

context.text: A third and final constitutional shortcoming of the North Carolina statute is its failure to allow the particularized consideration of relevant aspects of the character and record of each convicted defendant before the imposition upon him of a sentence of death.

context.text: A process that accords no significance to relevant facets of the character and record of the individual offender or the circumstances of the particular offense, excludes from consideration in fixing the ultimate punishment of death, the possibility of compassionate or mitigating factors stemming from the diverse frailties of humankind.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: It treats all persons convicted of a designated offense not as uniquely individual human beings, but as members of a faceless, undifferentiated mass to be subjected to the blind infliction of the penalty of death.

context.speaker: Potter Stewart
context.text: While the prevailing practice of individualizing sentencing determinations generally reflects simply enlightened policy, rather than a constitutional imperative, we believe and when I say we I mean Mr. Justice Powell, Mr. Justice Stevens and I believe that in a capital case, the fundamental respect for humanity underlying the Eighth Amendment, requires consideration of the character and record of the individual offender and the circumstances of the particular offense as a constitutionally indispensable part of the process of inflicting the death penalty.
